channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: E.U. Foreign Ministers Back Military Support for Kurds in Northern Iraq
item.description: The unanimous endorsement came at a meeting in Brussels on the crisis in northern Iraq where Islamist militants have besieged towns, and the Kurdish and Yazidi minorities.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By DAVID JOLLY
item.media:description: Ursula von der Leyen, Germany's defense minister, looks on as humanitarian aid bound for Iraq is loaded onto an Air Force plane.

item.title: Nigel Farage Picks District to Make Run for British Parliament
item.description: The leader of the U.K. Independence Party, which seeks Britain’s withdrawal from the European Union, said he would run next year in Thanet South.
item.dc:creator: By STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Militants Attack 2 Air Bases in Western Pakistan
item.description: The attacks in Baluchistan Province came to light as a more pressing threat to the government, a large protest march, approached the capital.
item.dc:creator: By SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: Ebola Epidemic Most Likely Much Larger Than Reported, W.H.O. Says
item.description: More than 1,100 deaths have been reported in four African nations, but the World Health Organization said the actual number is almost certainly higher.
item.dc:creator: By NICK CUMMING-BRUCE

item.title: Pierre Ryckmans, 78, Dies; Exposed Mao’s Hard Line
item.description: He challenged the prevailing romantic view of Mao harbored by many Western intellectuals by writing about the cruelties of the Cultural Revolution.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL FORSYTHE
item.media:description: Pierre Ryckmans, who used the pen name Simon Leys, first traveled to China as a student in 1955. His once romantic view of China dissipated when he learned of the Cultural Revolution.

item.title: Ukraine Says It Destroyed Military Vehicles Crossing Border From Russia
item.description: NATO and Ukraine said vehicles crossed into Ukraine and were destroyed by Ukrainian artillery fire but it was unclear whether they were carrying separatists or Russian soldiers.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW ROTH and ANDREW HIGGINS
item.media:description: A convoy of trucks said to be carrying aid await inspection in the town of Kamensk-Shakhtinsky, Russia, near the Ukrainian border.

item.title: Facing Both ISIS Militants and Bashar al-Assad’s Forces in Syria
item.description: Western-backed insurgents express frustration that the United States has not aided them as a mutual ally against both ISIS and President Bashar al-Assad.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD
item.media:description: The site of a reported attack by government forces on Wednesday in Aleppo, Syria.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Remembering Pierre Ryckmans
item.description: Pierre Ryckmans, who wrote under the pen name Simon Leys and was one of the world’s pre-eminent scholars of Chinese art, literature and culture, died on Monday in Sydney, Australia.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL FORSYTHE
item.media:description: Pierre Ryckmans at his home in Canberra, Australia, on Apr. 1, 1998.

item.title: To Reassure Baltic Allies, Obama Will Visit Estonia
item.description: The president will meet with the leaders of Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania concerning the conflict in Ukraine and the administration’s commitment to NATO.
item.dc:creator: By JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS

item.title: U.S. Military Deaths in Afghanistan
item.description: The Department of Defense has identified 2,328 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Boko Haram Abduct Dozens of Boys in Northeast Nigeria, Say Witnesses
item.description: Suspected Islamist Boko Haram fighters have abducted dozens of boys and men in a raid on a remote village in northeast Nigeria.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: With Eye on China, Abe Skips Visit to War Shrine
item.description: Some 80 Japanese politicians, including three members of Prime Minister Shinzo Abe’s cabinet, did visit Yasukuni, the large shrine in central Tokyo.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Anti-Semitism Stirs in Latin America
item.description: The region isn't particularly anti-Semitic, but there are signs it may become so.
item.dc:creator: By ENRIQUE KRAUZE

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Does the U.S. Still Have the Will to Lead?
item.description: Despite their resentment of American power, most Europeans still look to Washington to act in a crisis.
item.dc:creator: By CLEMENS WERGIN

item.title: Op-Ed Contributors: Handmaiden to Africa's Generals
item.description: Security in Africa can only be achieved by supporting diplomacy, democracy and development.
item.dc:creator: By ALEX DE WAAL and ABDUL MOHAMMED

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: After Tigers and Flies, Now a Spider: Jiang Zemin
item.description: Images purporting to show the name of the former leader Jiang Zemin being taken down from public buildings have caused a stir, reflecting expectations that his influence must go to pave the way for President Xi Jinping’s program of change for China.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: Jiang Zemin, former president of China and secretary general of the Communist Party, in 2012. He has retained enormous influence through a network of allies in the party.

item.title: Modi Promises Bank Accounts for All Families in India
item.description: The plan announced by Prime Minister Narendra Modi, if successful, could let the government turn subsidies for food, fuel and fertilizer into cash transfers.
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY
item.media:description: Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India delivering his Independence Day speech in New Delhi on Friday.

item.title: North Korea Says Rocket Launches Had Nothing to Do With Pope’s Visit
item.description: North Korea said that the rockets it fired the previous day had not been meant to coincide with the start of Pope Francis’ five-day visit to South Korea.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Russia’s Import Ban Creates ‘Huge Opportunity’ for China Growers
item.description: Russia’s recent decision to bar most food imports from Western countries has Chinese produce companies well-positioned to fill the void.
item.dc:creator: By BREE FENG
item.media:description: A vendor packing apples in a market in Changzhi, in the northern Chinese province of Shanxi. Russia’s ban on many Western food products has created openings for Chinese exporters.

item.title: Health Officials Try to Quell Fear of Ebola Spreading by Air Travel
item.description: The organization reacted after Korean Airlines suspended flights to Kenya, which is not among the countries afflicted by the Ebola outbreak.
item.dc:creator: By NICK CUMMING-BRUCE
item.media:description: A warning in Ivory Coast. The illness has appeared in Liberia, Sierra Leone, Guinea and Nigeria.

item.title: U.N. Pursues Bid to Stifle Rebels in Iraq
item.description: Galvanized by the brutality of Islamist militants, the United Nations Security Council appeared set to approve a resolution aimed at severely weakening them.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Open Source: Advice for Ferguson’s Protesters From the Middle East
item.description: Activists in the Middle East responded to the situation in the St. Louis suburb of Ferguson by offering online tips to protesters.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: U.S. Pulls Back on Plans for a Mountain Rescue
item.description: Far fewer refugees were discovered on a mountain in Iraq, a U.S. team reported, and they were no longer either starving or stranded.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:description: United States fighter jets took off in the Persian Gulf on Monday to attack Sunni militants in Iraq.

item.title: A Ukraine City Under Siege, ‘Just Terrified of the Bombing’
item.description: Life in Luhansk, Ukraine, is tough, but far from catastrophic. The only relief most people here seek is from the shelling, which goes on night and day.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: Russian Convoy Draws Stern Warning From Ukraine and Stops Short of Border
item.description: The convoy of around 260 trucks came within miles of the Ukrainian border on Thursday but was diverted to a Russian military base near Kamensk-Shakhtinsky.
item.category: Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe
International Committee of the Red Cross
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW ROTH and ANDREW HIGGINS
item.media:description: The Ukraine-bound convoy paused on Thursday near Kamensk-Shakhtinsky, Russia.
